column4: I have got "*** glibc detected *** double free or corruption " problem with nearly all applications; how can I solve this in a generic way ?
Ouch.... is this with all apps ?
several
Dapper by upgrade ?
stil breezy (?)
Um... not sure what could be wrong :-/ That's usually a coding error ...
I would try "sudo aptitude reinstall glibc" but I'm not sure it will help ... is it up to date ?
how the hell upgrade to a not freezing glibc ? I have had this bug on many distros ... and generic fix is: upgrade glibc !
updated yesterday and this morning
I've never had this problem :-/ It could be a gcc bug as well, I'm not sure....
actually Firefox 1.5 (after I upgraded FF because original was already buggy )
Well, try http://wiki.ubuntu.com/DebuggingProgramCrash to get a backtrace of a program that crashes
MALLOC_CHECK_=0 didnt help
It could be a bug in some other library, not glibc (I don't really think it is anyway)- the backtrace may help to pinpoint the library
MALLOC_CHECK_=0 DOES help (mistake was that I forgot the trailing '_'  )
Sorry - what is that MALLOC_CHECK ?
Gentoo's solution against this bug :)
What uses that variable? Heh, I've never heard of it before (and i've used gentoo )
http://bugs.gentoo.org/show_bug.cgi?id=81255 :) all Skype users known this; for FireFox on ubuntu, I have binded the desktop icon to a personal script doing: export MALLOC_CHECK_=0 ; firefox $1
ty :) I'll read up on it
I am now looking for a way to declare this variable for the whole machine, so that all users can inherit this fix, and also for all applications (OOo also bugs); which /etc/??? would help ?
I think it's /etc/environment
echo "MALLOC_CHECK_=0" >>/etc/environment ; reboot; enjoy :)
